'In keeping with elven tradition, the gift was given through a song. They called it the song of creation, for it was the creation of a new life for them. At least, so we thought...'
If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Amlodd. You'll find it on the bottom level, to the west. The light will guide the way...
Then I have nothing more to give. If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Amlodd. You'll find it on the bottom level, to the west. The light will guide the way...
'...With all my knowledge, I should have known not to meddle. That which I intended as a gift, soon turned out to be their curse.'
'The song of creation increased their lifespans, but at a terrible price. It bound them to me. To stray too far from their sides, caused pain, and even death.'
'I knew I had to help them, to fix my mistakes. I should have known that I'd only make it worse...'
If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Meilyr. You'll find it on the top level, to the west. The light will guide the way...
Then I have nothing more to give. If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Meilyr. You'll find it on the top level, to the west. The light will guide the way...
'...Another being came to our world. Divine like myself, but not by design. He spoke of a perfect world, one filled with power.'
'I knew it was a risk, but I decided to travel there. The power he spoke of might have been the only thing capable of saving the elves.'
'The curse made it impossible for me to go without them, so they had to come with me, and leave their home behind. It was hard on them, but in the end, I managed to convince them...'
If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Hefin. You'll find it on the top level, to the south west. The light will guide the way...
Then I have nothing more to give. If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Hefin. You'll find it on the top level, to the south west. The light will guide the way...
'...We made our home in the new world, in a great city of crystal spires. It was as beautiful as the world from which we came. But beneath that beauty, the curse remained.'
'The power that filled the world was even greater than I had anticipated. A higher power, one I had not encountered for a long time.'
'I was sure this world held the key to breaking the curse, I just needed to find it...'
If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Trahaearn. You'll find it on the top level, to the east. The light will guide the way...
Then I have nothing more to give. If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Trahaearn. You'll find it on the top level, to the east. The light will guide the way...
'...It took millennia, but I finally made a breakthrough. Deep beneath the mountains near our home, I found a source of deathly energy.'
'I was sure I could use this power to save them. My essence is of life, of light. This darkness would be the perfect counter, a way to nullify the curse.'
'I should have known not to be so foolish. This curse started with my meddling, my meddling was never going to end it...'
If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Iorwerth. You'll find it on the middle level, to the north east. The light will guide the way...
Then I have nothing more to give. If you seek more of the knowledge, look to the Seal of Iorwerth. You'll find it on the middle level, to the north east. The light will guide the way...
'...I am a being of light, but even within me, there was some darkness. I poured this darkness into my creation, combining it with the deathly energy I had found.'
'When I was done, I looked upon my creation. A fragment of myself, but one of darkness, rather than light. I thought her essence would counter my own, ending the curse with her mere existence.'

'It was not to be though. The curse was tied to me, not to her. I had failed, and she knew it. She turned on me, tried to destroy me. I had to stop her, so I sealed her away, in the very place I had created her...'
So Seren split off a fragment of herself, hoping it would help fix her mistakes. That's what lives within the Temple of Light, that's what Lord Iorwerth is trying to summon.
I should return to Lletya and let the others know what I've discovered.
Can you take me somewhere else?
Then I have nothing more to give. If you wish to hear a different piece of knowledge, look to the other seals. The light will guide the way...
Your work in the library, is it done?
It is.
Then you should speak with Arianwyn at once.
I... Hello.
I'm done with the library.
I see... You should tell Arianwyn.
Hey. You'd better speak with Arianwyn if you're done in the library.
, you have returned. Did you discover anything in the Grand Library?
I did. I think we should call the others.
I see. I will summon them at once.
Okay, thank you all for joining us. In case you weren't aware, here has returned from the Grand Library with some news for us.
So what happened?
I entered the library and found the seal broken by Lord Iorwerth.
So he did break one of the seals. Did it hide anything notable?
Yes, it contained a memory, left behind by Seren herself.
A memory of Seren? Amazing!
It was only part of something larger though. I had to break the other eight seals to uncover the rest of it.
So you managed to break all of Seren's seals? Very impressive. Now tell us, this memory, what was it?
That's where it gets interesting... The memory spoke of a curse on the elves, a curse that Seren was desperately trying to break.
A curse? What curse?
A curse binding the elves to Seren. As long as she remained close, it was unnoticeable, but if she went too far... pain, and death.
But who was responsible? Who cursed our people?
That's the thing... It was Seren herself.
What?
Seren was our goddess, she would never curse us. How dare you suggest otherwise!
I'm telling the truth!
Truth? You don't know the meaning of the word!
Let them finish Ysgawyn!
She didn't mean to do it, she was trying to help. She was using her own essence to try and extend your lifespans, it just went wrong...
I... I don't believe it. She cursed us? Our goddess cursed us?
If... If what you say is true, how does it relate to Lord Iorwerth's claims?
Seren went to great lengths to undo the curse. She believed that she could nullify it by creating a being of darkness, one to counter her light essence.
You don't mean...
Lord Iorwerth spoke the truth. She created a fragment of herself, filled with darkness, hoping to use it to break the curse. It didn't work though, so she sealed it in the Temple of Light.
I... I don't...
This can't be real... This is a dream... Tell me this isn't real!
This is a lie! It has to be! The human is showing their true colours once again!
Boy, what did I tell you about insulting the human!
Arianwyn? What do we do?
Arianwyn?
Why are we still stood here? This human needs putting in chains!
Arianwyn? Do something!
I... I don't...
Arianwyn!
I don't know what to do!
I don't know what to do...
You think I know something you all don't? You think I have some trick hidden up my sleeve? I have nothing!
You're our leader! Lead!
And how would you have me do that, Ysgawyn? How am I meant to respond to this?
You can start by locking this human up. They are a traitor! The curse is clearly a lie!
If we were truly tied to Seren, we'd have all dropped dead when she was shattered! The curse clearly doesn't exist!
Well... Don't be so sure of that.
Nice of you to suddenly speak up! I'd have thought a king would command a bit of authority rather than crying in the corner!
I'm not a king any more...
Well thank Seren for that! You only managed to lose the entire kingdom to Lord Iorwerth!
You should learn some respect!
I have respect! I respect the heroes who died in this war, not the coward that ran away from it!
You... You're right. I failed you, I failed you all. I wish I could go back and change that, but I can't. All I can do now, is try and make things right.
While horrifying, I believe speaks the truth. They have no reason to lie to us, and what they say does make sense.
How?
Most of you never met Seren. You only know her through the stories passed down to you. But I did know her, and I know she was filled with pain.
You... You think this is the reason?
I think it could be. As for why we don't feel the effects of the curse now, that is because Seren is still with us, every one of us.
Of course, the crystal seeds. All of us carry them in some form or other, and all of them came from Seren when she shattered herself.
Her last attempt to break the curse, after everything else failed...
So what do we do?
There's one other thing. Seren built a second set of defences within the Temple of Light, this fragment of her is sealed within them. There's an orb that can bypass these defences.
An orb?
Yes, apparently she hid it somewhere called Gorlah.
I know of Gorlah. It's an old shrine north of Prifddinas, a place for quiet worship away from the city.
Does Lord Iorwerth know about the orb?
Yes.
Then he might already have claimed it. We should send someone to check.
I will go. I wish to see some actual proof of what this human claims.
That's not your call. Arianwyn is in charge here.
Am I? My whole life, I've been fighting Lord Iorwerth. My whole life, I've believed him to be a servant of Zamorak. Now I learn that everything I fought for was a lie.
I don't even know what I'm leading any more...
Maybe Lord Iorwerth fights for a different cause to what we thought, but that doesn't change who he is, that doesn't change what he's done.
I need time alone... Time to think... Baxtorian, I would appreciate it if you could take charge for a while.
Oh... I... I'll do my best.
That's all I ask. Now, I would like to be alone.
You're not the only one. I think we all need time to process this.
Then let us close this meeting. We will reconvene later.
So what do we do now?
There's a lot to think about, for all of us. There's also a lot we still don't know.
Do you think Arianwyn will be okay?
I hope so... I know the pain he feels, it can tear you apart if you're not careful.
You seem to be dealing with it okay.
I'm glad it seems that way, that's not how it feels though. I knew of Seren's troubles, but to know the cause... it's heart-breaking.
Now I find myself leading once more, something I swore I would never do again.
Arianwyn seems to think you're capable.
Yes... But Arianwyn doesn't know me, not really.
Anyway, I suppose my job now is to make sure we don't lose sight of our goal.
Do we know what that is anymore?
To stop Lord Iorwerth. Even if we now know his true intentions, even if some think those intentions may be good, we can't ignore his actions.
He'd see us all dead just to free this fragment of Seren. He has to be stopped.
What do you need me to do?
Ysgawyn has gone to see if he can find the orb you spoke of. No one actually gave him permission, but he seems to care little for orders at the moment.

Once he gets back we'll know more about what to do next. In the meantime, I've managed to decipher the clues left behind by Lord Crwys and Lady Hefin, two more of the clan elders. We should try to find them.
How do I find Lord Crwys?
Here is the clue he left behind: 'The trees of my home will call to me.'
The Crwys clan is a clan of woodcutters and farmers. The entire clan is close to nature, but none more than Lord Crwys.
How do I find Lady Hefin?
Here is the clue she left behind: 'I will walk across the water to the south.'

The Hefin clan are our religious leaders. They teach us to better ourselves, not just in mind, but in body as well. Lady Hefin used to lead some of the more vigorous training exercises of the Hefin clan.
You should try and find Lord Crwys and Lady Hefin. They could be of big help to us in the fight against Lord Iorwerth.
Ahh... Stop, stop stop!
Oh... You're not a tree.
A tree? No of course not! I am an elf, but through deep magic, I took on the form of a tree. It allowed me to hide, to stay safe.
Safe from Lord Iorwerth?
You know of Lord Iorwerth?
Yes. You must be Lord Crwys, Baxtorian sent me to find you. We need your help.
I see. Where is Baxtorian?
The village of Lletya. It's east of here.
Then it is time for me to uproot. I will head there at once.
It's strange to be an elf again. I spent so long living as a tree I almost forgot what my true form felt like.
Maybe the tree was your true form and this is just your disguise.
Hmmm. Now there's an interesting thought...
A traveller? It's been a long time since I've had any company on this little island of mine.
I fear you are at a dead end though, there's nothing of interest for you here.
Don't be so sure. I got here by following a clue, a clue left behind by Lady Hefin. I seek her on behalf of Baxtorian himself.
Baxtorian? I see. Then I have good news for you human, you have found the one you seek.
So you're Lady Hefin?
I am. I have lived here in solitude for a long time, but now that solitude must end. Where am I needed?
The village of Lletya, north of here.
Then it is time to resume my role among the elves. I will go at once.
The road to enlightenment is a perilous one. The latest peril is the largest I've ever seen though.
Do you think we can overcome it.
That is not for me to say. All I can do is see where this path takes me. And if this is the final step of my journey, then I go to my end willingly.
Oh... Hello. Good work finding Lord Crwys and Lady Hefin. I never thought I'd see the other elders again, maybe we'll have a chance with them alongside us.
No problem. Any news from Ysgawyn?
He has just returned. Let us gather the others and hear what he has to say.
Now that Ysgawyn has returned, I thought we should gather to hear what he has discovered.
Where is Arianwyn?
I saw him heading out into the forest earlier. He must have wanted some time alone.
I hope he's okay.
He'll be alright, just give him time. While he is gone, we need to keep making progress.
On that note, what news do you have, Ysgawyn?
The shrine at Gorlah was empty. The orb was removed quite a while ago by the looks of things.
So do you believe me now?
If it helps with your overinflated ego, then yes, I now believe you.
If the orb isn't at Gorlah, Lord Iorwerth must have claimed it. It could be anywhere now.
Well luckily for us, I know exactly where it is. There's a cave just north of the Iorwerth Camp that is used to store supplies. Lord Iorwerth has it under close guard there.
How do you know this?
Because I went scouting.
Scouting? At the Iorwerth Camp? Who gave you permission?
I gave myself permission. I do not serve you, Baxtorian, or anyone else here.
No, you just serve yourself, don't you Ysgawyn?
My actions benefit us all! Now that we know where the orb is, we can move to claim it.
But why would Lord Iorwerth keep the orb at the camp? Surely it would be more secure behind the Prifddinas walls.
That's the other thing I found out. Lord Iorwerth knows we managed to enter the library. He fears the orb would not be safe behind the walls.
How did you discover this?
I have my methods...
It worries me that you are unwilling to share them.
Save your suspicions for someone who cares.
So we know where the orb is. What do we do now?
Lord Iorwerth intends to use the orb to free the dark fragment of Seren. We need to stop him.
But this fragment of Seren, it's still part of her. Lord Iorwerth has done some unspeakable things, but he doesn't serve Zamorak like we thought, maybe we can reason with him.
I tried to reason with Lord Iorwerth a long time ago... It won't work, as much as I wish it would.
Regardless of his intentions, Lord Iorwerth is our enemy. You should want to kill him, not reason with him.
I would never wish for the death of a fellow elf, no matter what they've done.
Well look at you with your moral high ground.
Now is not the time for arguing. At some point, we will need to decide what to do about the fragment of Seren. For now though, we need to focus on getting that orb and stopping Lord Iorwerth.
The orb isn't enough for him to win though, he'll also need to break through the defences on the Temple of Light. He'll struggle to do that now he's lost Ardougne.
There is another way into the temple though, a tunnel from the Underground Pass, built by the dwarves there.
Great... Dwarves... I hate dwarves.
You hate everything Ysgawyn.
Lord Iorwerth will stop at nothing to enter the temple. We have to assume that sooner or later, he will find that tunnel.
Then we should make sure the tunnel is secure. Baxtorian, allow myself and the other elders to go meet with these dwarves.
Very well, head to the Underground Pass and see what you can do. In the meantime, we should secure that orb. Even if he does get into the temple, Lord Iorwerth can do nothing without it.
Let me guess, you're going to send your favourite human.
Jealous, Ysgawyn?
No. I have other things to do anyway.
, head to the cave at the Iorwerth Camp and recover the Orb of Light. Be careful though, it's likely to be well guarded.
Sounds like we're done here. Let's get moving.
Head to the cave at the Iorwerth Camp and recover the Orb of Light. Be careful though, it's likely to be well guarded.
Who are you?
Well prepare to die !
Uh oh...
I've managed to recover the orb.
Thank you friend. Without this, Lord Iorwerth has no hope of freeing that fragment of Seren. I will look after it until we decide what to do with it.
So what now?
We have the orb, and the elders are securing the Temple of Light as we speak. That fragment of Seren should no longer be a concern.
But?
Lord Iorwerth is still out there and thanks to his larger army, we have no way of easily dealing with him.
There must be something we can do.
I'm sure there is, but I don't know what.
Perhaps we should call the others then.
I was thinking the same. However, I have a favour to ask first. Something I'd rather keep quiet.
What is it?
Our group is fractured. The revelation about Seren has hit everyone hard, and opinions clearly differ on how we should be responding to it. I fear some intend to take matters into their own hands.
Ysgawyn in particular has been very distant. I have concerns about his loyalties.
You don't think he'd join with Lord Iorwerth do you?
I don't know. He claims to hate the Iorwerth clan, and he has more reason to feel that way than most. That said... something isn't right.
And you want me to investigate?
I do. Ysgawyn left the village after the meeting earlier. See if you can track him down and find out what he's up to.
Any idea where he might have gone?
I'm afraid not. Elena said she saw him leaving though, maybe she can help.
Ysgawyn has been acting suspiciously. See if you can find him and work out what he's up to. Elena said she saw him leaving the village. She might know where he went.
Hey Elena, how's it going?
Not too bad. I've been given a lot to think about though. Everything I've learnt about Seren, about the elves... it's crazy how big it all is. Our little fight in Ardougne seems so small now.
I'm surprised it hasn't made you run for the hills.
Now you know me better than that, I'm too stubborn to leave now.
Why are you still here though?
It's about closure I guess. So many people were hurt by Lord Iorwerth's actions in West Ardougne. I need to know that he'll never hurt them again.
He seems to think his actions are necessary.
Maybe his cause is just, but that doesn't give him the right to ruin lives in the way he has.
What do you think should happen to him if we win?
You mean do I think he should die?
I've tried to dedicate my life to helping people, healing them. I think all lives are valuable, even the lives of people like Lord Iorwerth.
I think Lord Iorwerth should face justice for what he has done. I don't think killing him is justice though. Maybe that makes me weak, but that's how I feel.
I don't think it makes you weak, it makes you strong.
You do? Thank you, that means a lot, especially from you.
I realise I must come across as so self-righteous with all of this. I'm sorry about that.
As much as I hate it, I know that sometimes death is the only option. I like to think we can consider alternatives though. It's what sets us apart from the enemy.
He needs to pay for what he's done though.
He does, but does it need to be with his life? Killing is a solution, but maybe it's not the only one.
I'm sorry. I realise I must come across as so self- righteous talking like this. I'm not trying to act better than anyone, I just want to make sure we've considered every option.
Sometimes people have to die for things to change.
I suppose... I just can't help but wonder if there might be another way.
Anyway, did you want something?
Yes. I wanted to ask you about Ysgawyn.
That's fair. Anyway, I wanted to ask you about Ysgawyn.
Very true. Anyway, I'll see you later.
Ysgawyn?
Yes. I'm trying to find him. Baxtorian said you saw him leaving the village earlier.
I did. I don't know where he went though.
Hmm. That's annoying.
He only left recently, maybe you can pick up his trail. Have a look around the hidden entrance to the village, by the wolves, and see if you can find anything out of place.
Good idea. Thanks Elena.
Hey. Thanks for the talk earlier, it meant a lot. I won't keep you, I'm sure you've got things to do. See you later
Hi there. I'm sure you've got things to do. You should probably go do them.
Well well! Meeting with the Iorwerth clan, Ysgawyn? This doesn't look good for you!
You! What are you doing here?
Keeping an eye on you, you traitor!
Traitor? You dare call me a traitor? Your loyalties change more than the wind and you have the nerve to say I'm the traitor?
Lord Iorwerth took everything from me! My whole life was destroyed by him and that dog, Essyllt! Do you really think I'd join up with them?
Well that's what it looks like!
You fool of a human! I may not agree much with the other rebels but everything I've done has been to stop Lord Iorwerth!
Well who's this then?
Well now that you've ruined everything as usual, I suppose I'd better tell you.
This is Iestin Edern, head of research for Lord Iorwerth, and my informant within the Iorwerth clan.
Wait... Your informant?
That's right you idiot! Iestin here has been providing me with information on the Iorwerth clan. Not only that, he is the reason why you were able to claim that Orb of Light.
But... I don't understand. If you've always been loyal, why all the secrecy?
That was my request. I feared that the other rebels may not be trusting of me. They could have imprisoned me or even killed me. It seemed safer to keep things secret.
Not to mention the fact that it kept Iestin safe from any informants that Lord Iorwerth might have among the rebels.
I... I see... I guess that all makes sense.
I'm sorry Ysgawyn.
I don't want an apology! I don't care how you feel about me. All I care about is stopping Lord Iorwerth for good. I lost all that I had, all that I cared about! I will make him pay!
Arianwyn told me what they did. I...
No! You don't get to talk about that! You have no right!
I'm sorry...
Sorry to interrupt, but I think you need to hear this.
Yes. What news do you bring Iestin?
So what have you been discussing?
Before you interrupted, Iestin was about to give me some news. Go ahead Iestin.
It's not good I'm afraid. The human here was not wrong to suspect a betrayal. Lord Iorwerth, he knows about Lletya.
By Seren! How?
There is a traitor amongst your people. I know not who they are, but it wasn't this human as you feared. They told Lord Iorwerth how to find the village.
When did he find out?
Earlier today. Essyllt is preparing their forces as we speak.
Essyllt!
Hang on... If the traitor was one of the rebels, they'll also have told Lord Iorwerth about the tunnel into the Temple of Light!
He'll know how to get in... He just needs to reclaim the orb! We need to get to Lletya now!
What about me?
Your days as an informant are done. You're coming with us. Now we need to move!
Elena! Are you okay?
I'm fine. We need to get the citizens to safety!
Where's Baxtorian? Where's the orb?
Sorry, but I don't know.
Dammit! Right, you two go with Elena and help the citizens. I'll find Baxtorian.
But...
But nothing! Now go!
My children! Someone help me find my children!
, you go help Mawrth. We'll get the other citizens to safety.
My children are hiding in there! Please find them! Please save them!
Are you okay?
I... I'm scared...
You have to be brave. Your mother is outside waiting for you.
Okay... I can be brave!
What's happening? Where's mummy?
She's outside, can you get to her?
I... I think so...
Don't worry, you can do this!
Lord Iorwerth!
Go! I'll get Mawrth and the other citizens to safety!
Well well, the great King Baxtorian. I wasn't sure I believed it when I heard you were still alive, but here you are.
I'm sorry to disappoint you.
Well your ability to disappoint is one of your few talents, so I'll let it slide. However, I must insist that you give me the orb.
Crawl back into the hole you came from Lord Iorwerth, you won't leave here with that orb!
Oh I will, one way or another. But in case it wasn't clear, let me explain the situation.
As we speak, my forces are dealing with the last of your rebels and rounding up your citizens. You have no way to fight, and nowhere to run.

Of course, I could just have you all killed right now. After the trouble you've all caused me, it wouldn't be an unreasonable act. However, I am not without mercy, and I will not draw blood unless I have to.
Instead, I give you a choice. Give me the orb, and I will withdraw my forces, leaving you in peace. Refuse, and the blood of those citizens will be on your hands.
We do not barter with your kind!
I feared as much. That said, I do have someone here who might change your mind.
Arianwyn!
What is this? What have you done?
What have I done? Well I told him the truth. It was about time that someone did.
What truth?
They're not the enemy. I thought they were, for so long, but they're not.
Everything we have done, every sacrifice we have made, all of it has been to free our goddess.
You've never sacrificed, you've never lost anything. You only sacrifice those around you...
You have some nerve to lecture me. Remind me, how many of your people died under your watch? How many fell, trying to free your wife?
These new followers of yours, do they know? Do they know what you did? Do they know about the monster you truly are?
I never...
No... of course they don't. You're a liar and a coward, that's all you've ever been.
As for me, I'm many things, and I admit, a lot of them aren't good. But I would never throw lives away like you did.
What's he on about?
Nothing... He's lying. He's just trying to justify his mistakes.
I've done many terrible things, but none of them were a mistake. Every sacrifice I've made has been for her, for Seren.
And what are these apparent sacrifices you've made? Nothing compared to the suffering you've caused me, I'm sure!
When I first discovered the truth, our clan was still ruled by my mother. I went to her, told her what I'd found, told her what we needed to do.
I loved my mother, but she was blindly loyal to this fool here, she wouldn't have any of it. I couldn't just abandon my goddess though, she needed us. So I did what had to be done.
You killed her?
And I would do it again without hesitation. For Seren, there is no price too great.
You're a monster! Surely you don't mean to side with this barbarian, Arianwyn.
I don't condone what he did, what any of them have done. But they want what we want, we have to try working together.
I'll die before working with them.
No one else needs to die here. Please, just give me the orb. Do that, and I swear we will do you no further harm.
I... I can't.
I see. I did hope it wouldn't come to this, but you've given me no choice. Morvran.
What's going on? Where's mummy?
I'll make this simple for you, Baxtorian. The life of the boy is now in your hands. Give me the orb, and no harm will come to him.
You wouldn't...
No, I wouldn't. But the choice is not mine, it's yours. I will count to five.
One.
Lord Iorwerth, please...
Two.
Baxtorian, please. Just give him the orb.
Three.
I don't like this, I want mummy!
Four.
Stop!
I'll give you the orb. Just please, don't hurt anyone else.
A wise choice, must be a first for you.
No!
Ysgawyn!
Get after them!
Arianwyn...
It wasn't meant to go like this. No one was meant to get hurt. I'm sorry.
I don't understand... why?
For so long I was led to believe that Lord Iorwerth was our enemy. I thought he'd turned his back on Seren, thought he'd betrayed her.
But I was wrong. Everything we thought we were fighting for was a lie. He never betrayed her, everything he did was to free her.
Whatever it is he's trying to free... it isn't her.
How do you know? Because of what you found in the library? How do we know that was her? How do we know what's true anymore?
So that's why you turned to Lord Iorwerth? To find out the truth?
My whole life I've dreamed of her, dreamed of what it would be like to meet her. If there's even a chance that she's still alive, I have to know.
And if she is alive? Then what?
Seren guided the elves for thousands of years. With her back, we'll finally be able to reform Prifddinas. We'll finally have peace again.
Peace? Look around you Arianwyn. Look at what Lord Iorwerth has done to this village, your home. Does this look like the work of someone who wants peace?
It doesn't have to be this way. Step aside. Let me stop Lord Iorwerth and reclaim the orb. Once he's dealt with, we can find out the truth, our way.
You... you know I can't do that.
Arianwyn please...
I'm sorry friend, but I've made my choice. Now please, walk away. No one else needs to die here.
I can't let him get away.
And I can't let you go after him.
So be it.
Ysgawyn...
He wasn't a friend, to any of us. Everything he cared about he lost a long time ago.
But he didn't give up. To the very end, he fought for a cause he believed in, our cause.
And now he's gone. Along with the orb and that traitor, Arianwyn. Lord Iorwerth has everything he needs now. He'll be preparing to move on the temple as we speak.
We can't give up Islwyn. If we do, then he died for nothing.
Oh I don't intend to give up, but make no mistake, this is a fight we're unlikely to win.
So what do we do? Baxtorian?
I... I don't think there's anything we can do. Lord Iorwerth will destroy us if we try to stop him.
Maybe, but we have to try. What else is there?
We'd be throwing lives away...
Well Lord Iorwerth seemed to think you were no stranger to that. Why did he think that?
I don't know, probably just some lie he tells himself.
Hmm. I don't believe you.
You'd trust Lord Iorwerth over me?
I wouldn't trust Lord Iorwerth if my life depended on it. I know a liar when I see one though, and I can tell you're not being honest about something.
What happened? Tell us.

It was after we were defeated by Lord Iorwerth. With Prifddinas lost to us, we returned to our kingdom in the east. We'd been gone for years by then, and in our absence, the kingdom had fallen to our other foes.
So many dead... my people, the ones I was meant to protect. But that wasn't the worst of it. Glarial, my beloved, she was taken from me.
We searched far and wide, desperate to find her. At times it felt like we were close, but the enemy always managed to elude us.
Eventually, we managed to track her captors to some caves south of our ruined kingdom. It was clearly a trap, but I was a fool. I was so blind in my desire to find her, I didn't consider the obvious.
I sent my soldiers in, the few that I still had. They fought the best they could, but it was hopeless. They were massacred.
After that, I knew I couldn't carry on. I was alone and powerless. So I sealed myself away, in the hope that one day she would come back to me.
You... you killed them? You killed them all?
I did. But you don't understand, I loved my wife. If there was a chance of freeing her, I had to take it.
You think I don't understand love? I knew love, for Eirlys! My mother! Your daughter! She died in your war, while you hid away!
Lord Iorwerth was right! You're just a coward!
Islwyn, where are you going?
The Underground Pass! I intend to fight for my people, even if their own king won't!
I used to think I was a good king, one that took care of his people. Thanks to me, they had roofs over their heads and food for their tables.
And yet... I never loved them, not really. The only thing I loved was her, my Glarial.
When they took her from me... I was torn apart. I vowed I would get her back no matter the cost. That vow destroyed my people... I destroyed my people. In the end... I became just like Lord Iorwerth.
Maybe you did fail your people, you didn't destroy them though.
Maybe not then... but now...
You think this is over? Is that it? Lord Iorwerth beats us once so we just give up? If you truly think that then yes, you have destroyed your people!
Do you want to just rot here? Wallowing in your own self pity while you lose the little you still have?
What other option is there?
We can fight! Lord Iorwerth doesn't win until he gets into the Temple of Light! We can still stop this!
But he outnumbers us ten to one... We'll all die.
Surely it's better to die trying than to live a life of regret? I'd have thought you'd know that better than anyone.
I... I can't...

Oh for crying out loud! You have got to be the biggest waste of space I have ever met! I've met goblins with more of a spine than you! For once in your miserable life why don't you actually do something worthwhile?
You... You're awful at pep talks.
It wasn't meant to be a pep talk!
*sigh* Look... Ask yourself this... What would she want?
She... She'd want me to save them.
Then why are we still stood around talking? We've got work to do!
I... You're right... We don't have a plan though.
Lord Iorwerth only has one way into the Temple of Light, the dwarf tunnel from the Underground Pass. We need to stop him getting through.
How?
The dwarves should be able to seal the tunnel. We'll need to defend them while they do.
But we don't have the strength to withstand Lord Iorwerth's forces.
We have the clan elders, their combined power is an army in itself.
Not all the clan elders. We're still missing two.
Well have you deciphered their clues?
I have, but there's a problem. We should hopefully be able to find Lady Meilyr. But Lady Ithell, she died in the early days of the war.
That's not good. Did she have any descendants?
I had a look. Kelyn Ithell is her closest living relative. Problem is, we don't just need a Lady Ithell, we need the Lady Ithell.
Hmmm. How did she die?
An illness of some sort, I never actually knew what it was. She'd had it for years.
For years? So she'd have been ill when she gave you her clue. If she knew she was dying, maybe her clue reflects that.
What do you mean?
Knowledge can be passed on. Maybe the clue will lead us to her knowledge.
I... I suppose you could be right.
It's worth a shot at least. Leave it with me and I'll see what I can do. In the meantime, you should take the others to the dwarf camp in the Underground Pass.
See if you can get in contact with General Hining and the new king of Ardougne as well. Maybe they'll be willing to help us.
I'll see what I can do. We'll need to work quickly though, Lord Iorwerth will be preparing his forces as we speak. Now I guess you'll be wanting to hear those clues?
What's Lady Ithell's clue?
Here is the clue she left behind: 'I'll put my soul into my greatest work.'

The Ithell clan is a clan of builders and architects. Before her death, Lady Ithell was considered the finest architect of all the elves. This village was her final and finest contribution to our people.
What's Lady Meilyr's clue?
Here is the clue she left behind: 'Follow the scrolls to find me.'
The Meilyr clan is a clan of scientists and explorers. You'll probably need to do some exploring yourself to find Lady Meilyr. You may also find this of use.
Do you need to hear one of the clues again?
Still here, Iestin?
Well I can't really go back to Lord Iorwerth now. He knows I betrayed him.
No, but you don't have to stay here.
I've made my decision and I intend to stick by it.
So why follow him in the first place?
After we lost Seren, Baxtorian was chosen to lead us. Rather than looking after the city of Prifddinas, he chose to expand to the east, leaving us behind.
With no ruler, Prifddinas fell into chaos. When Lord Iorwerth came to us and said he'd found a way to bring Seren back to us, you can understand why we turned to him.
I wish things were as simple as good against evil, but that's rarely the case.
I suppose you're right. Anyway, I'd better get going.
Hey Elena. What are you up to?
Making sure I've got everything ready. I'll be leaving for the Underground Pass soon.
You're coming with us?
Well I've stuck around for this long, it would feel wrong to leave now. Besides, I may not be much of a fighter, but I can help in other ways.
Very true. I'll leave you to prepare.
Oh wow!
I... I see it! I see everything! All of her knowledge, I have it now!
Lady Ithell's knowledge?
Yes, I know everything that she knew! The statue, it must have given it to me somehow!
You're the closest living relative of Lady Ithell. Now you have her knowledge as well. I suppose that makes you the new Lady Ithell.
I... I suppose it does. Wow!
I guess you'll be wanting me to help defend the Underground Pass then? Well don't worry, I was planning on joining you anyway. With this new knowledge, I can be an even bigger help.
I'll head there right away. Time is of the essence.
At last Baxtorian calls to me. I can't say I expected him to send a human, but I suppose nothing is as expected these days.
We need your help. The final fight against Lord Iorwerth is nearly here.
I will join you in this darkest of hours. Where must I go?
The battle will take place in the Underground Pass. Head to Lletya first though, Baxtorian will meet you there.
As you wish.
Oh... Hello. Most of the others have departed for the Underground Pass. I'll be leaving with the rest soon.
Then I shall meet you there.
Don't take too long. We'll be at the dwarf camp.
How are you Islwyn?
As good as can be, all things considered. I idolised my grandfather for years. They always say you should never meet your heroes though, now I see why.
He's still your family though.
He is, he's the only family I have left. The rest of them died in his war. A war that will finally end today.
Maybe if we both survive, I'll find it in my heart to forgive him. But for now, I have to focus elsewhere.
I'll leave you to prepare.
Good luck. I'll see you on the other side.
Arianwyn is out there, walking alongside our greatest enemy.
He saved me once you know. Some of Lord Iorwerth's men found me in the forest. There were too many for me to fight off, I thought I was done for. Without Arianwyn, I wouldn't be here today.
But now he fights alongside them. This war has torn us apart, all of us.
Well it ends today.
Yes, today it ends... For better, or for worse.
I wonder if Essyllt will join the battle today.
What will you do if he does?
Me? Nothing. I'm not much of a fighter. I'll be helping with the wounded instead.
You though... If you see him, don't show him mercy, for he will show you none. Instead, you should show him what happens to those who hurt us.
For Ysgawyn?
No one liked him that much, but he was one of us, and he died trying to save us. He deserves justice.
If I get the chance, I'll make sure he gets it.
Thank you friend.
I'd better get going.
Those are my people coming for us. My brothers and sisters.
They were once, but not anymore. You're one of us now.
He's not evil you know, Lord Iorwerth. None of them are really, apart from Essyllt maybe.
Those that follow him, they do so because they believe in him, believe in what he's doing. For a long time, I believed in him as well.
So why did you betray him?
He became so obsessed with his cause, he forgot why we started following him in the first place. He became more extreme, more radical.
I tried to advise him as best I could, but over time he started listening more to Essyllt and less to me.
After I lost my brother, who died following Lord Iorwerth's orders, I realised he needed to be stopped before it was too late.
You made the right choice.
I hope so. But even now I find myself filled with doubt.
Nothing like a *hic* bit of home brew before getting to work.
Are you sure you should be drinking? We can't afford to make mistakes here.
Argh, I work better with a bit of *hic* brew in me. Nothing for you to *hic* worry about.
If you're sure.
Didn't think I'd see you back down here. The elves are lucky to have you on their side.
They're lucky to have you as well, you're our last hope.
What an awful thought. Four dwarves, one a drunk, are the final hope against this darkness. I hope we don't let you down.
You won't.
I hope you're right friend.
Take care Klank.
You too adventurer...
. We'll soon be ready to seal the tunnel, it's slow work I'm afraid.
How come?
If we do this wrong, we'll bring the entire cavern down upon all of us.
Well that would definitely stop Lord Iorwerth.
It would. I don't know about you though, but I intend to survive this day. Bringing the cavern down isn't a good way to achieve that.
True that. I'll leave you to your work.
Hey there.
How's it going Thorgel?
Apart from the army of elves about to descend on us, pretty good.
You'll be fine, you've got all of us to defend you.
Well let's hope your better at fighting than Kamen is at brewing, or this will be a short battle.
So here we are. At long last, the end is upon us. The only question that remains is who it's the end for.
You knew this day would come?
No war lasts forever, not even this one. The darkest verse of the song of the elves is upon us. Who knows what the next verse will be.
Lord Iorwerth better show up soon! I can't wait forever!
You seem keen.
I've lived for thousands of years. If I'm going to die today, I'd rather just get on with it.
Fair enough.
This is a dark place we've come to. Fitting I suppose, for this is to be our darkest hour.
Do you think the fragment of Seren is the cause of the darkness?
Possibly, I suspect it was here long before her though. And whatever happens today, I'm sure it will remain for long after.
The greatest battle of our time is almost upon us. We should take the time to reflect.
I've never really been one for looking backwards. I prefer to look ahead.
You can still reflect on the future as well as the past. If we survive today, our future will be changed forever.
I suppose. I'll probably wait until we've won to think about that though.
As you wish.
I hope we win today. It would be a bit embarrassing to be known as the shortest serving clan elder.
I bet. I'd also like to avoid death if possible. I suspect it's not very fun.
Not much is fun when Lord Iorwerth is involved. If all goes well though, he won't be a problem after today.
I've been on the run from Lord Iorwerth for centuries. I'll be glad to finally see peace.
So you think we'll win?
Don't forget that death is a form of peace.
I guess. I'd rather avoid it if I can though.
There are worse things in this world than death. Never forget that.
Good to see you General.
And you friend. It will be an honour to fight against the darkness alongside you. Together, we can avenge King Tyras.
You seem well prepared for the battle, compared to the rest of us at least.
We knew this battle would come, ever since the day our king died. We've been prepared for a long time.
I hope it's enough.
As do I. If it's not though, we'll make sure they remember us until the end of their days.
That we will.
Ah... You made it.
That I did. I see you managed to gather some allies.
Yes, General Hining has given us the full support of the Tyras forces. Sadly though, the new king of Ardougne does not wish to assist us.
Typical, after all we did for them.
I suppose they've had enough of elves.
Hmmm. How are the defences looking?
We've managed to fortify the area around the camp quite well. The dwarves have set up some cannons and General Hining's men have built some catapults.
Good. We may be outnumbered, but the defences will give us a fighting chance.
I hope so... I fear it won't be enough to win though.
We don't need to win, we just need to buy the dwarves enough time to seal that tunnel. Do we know how long they'll need?
They haven't given us an exact time, it's a slow process apparently.
Well I suppose we don't want them to do it wrong, they could bring the entire cavern down on top of us. Do we know where Lord Iorwerth is?
The scouts have reported that his forces are on the move as we speak. It won't be long.
Let's use the time wisely then. Is there anything I can do before the attack begins?
Elena said she had an idea that might help our defence. You could talk to her and see if she needs any help.
I'll get right on it.
Speak with Elena. She said she had an idea that might help our defence.
Hey. I think Baxtorian wants to talk to you.
So this is it, after everything that's happened, this is where it ends.
Are you afraid?
I... I am.
What about you?
I'm afraid too.
You... You matter to me you know...
You matter to me as well.
Elena?
Don't die today.
I... I'd better go.
Thank you, you're a good friend.
I'm not afraid.
I... I'm terrible at these moments. I never know what to say.
I care about you Elena, you know that right?
I... I don't know what to say either.
Good luck today.
I'd better go.
Baxtorian said you had an idea to help our defence.
That's right. One of the dwarves here, Kamen, has brewed up some strange alcohol. Whatever it is, it's very flammable.
Ah yes, I've made good use of it in the past.
Well I think we can make use of it again. I've combined the alcohol with some other chemicals. The result is quite explosive!
If we position some of these explosives on the approach to the camp, we can use them against the Iorwerth forces.
Hmmm, that could work quite well. Is there anything I can do to help?
I've dug some holes around the camp for the explosives to go in. Could you fill them in for me?
Here's the explosives. If you need more just let me know.
That's the last of them. I'd better get back to Baxtorian.
I think that's everything prepared.
Good, because we're out of time. A message came into the camp, Lord Iorwerth wishes to meet.
He wants to meet? Surely it's a trap?
Maybe, but I don't think so. Even if nothing came of it, he was willing to meet me before the Siege of Prifddinas all those years ago.
So what are you going to do?
I will go. If there's a chance to avoid bloodshed, we should take it, no matter how slim the odds are. I would like you to join me.
You think Lord Iorwerth will listen to me?
No, but maybe Arianwyn will. He considered you a friend, he may still care for what you have to say.
I see. Then I will join you.

Thank you friend. Now, Lord Iorwerth is unlikely to be patient, but we can spare a bit of time. If there's anyone you wish to talk to here, I suggest you do so before we depart. You may not get another chance.
Let me know when you're ready to go.
Then we will leave at once.
I'll be back soon.
Don't take too long. I'll be here when you're ready.
Lord Iorwerth.
King Baxtorian.
I'm not a king... not anymore.
No. You never really were a king though were you? A king doesn't abandon his people like you did.
I did not come here to trade insults.
Really? So why did you come then?
We came to put an end to this. To put aside our differences and stop this war before more people die needlessly.
You talk sense human, and yet you stand beside the warmonger himself.
You have a fair share of blood on your hands as well you know.
I do. I have done many unspeakable things, things that haunt me every day. But what I did, I did for the good of my people.
Whereas he, he only ever cared for himself.
Go on, deny it. Just like you always do.
I don't deny it. I failed my people, I failed you. I was never a worthy king, I know that now. But you can't use my failures as a mask to hide your own.
We can stand here going around in circles all day, you won't change my mind.
If you're not willing to change your mind, why even bother to meet us?
In the hope that I might still change yours. I don't want anyone else to die in this war. I give you the chance to stand down.
And what happens if we do?
We enter the temple, free our goddess and with her by our side, reform the city of Prifddinas.
And we all live happily ever after?
In a manner of speaking.
That temple, it doesn't contain your goddess. At best, it contains a shadow of what she once was.
Yes, Arianwyn told me what you discovered in the library. It matters not though, that is a part of our goddess in there, we have to free her.
And if she's evil? What do you do then?
My loyalty is to Seren, I will let her decide what is evil.
That... that's not what we agreed.
What?
We agreed to enter the temple and free Seren. If that's not Seren in there, we shouldn't free her.
I will keep my promise to you Arianwyn, you should not doubt that.
Why shouldn't he doubt that? You burnt his home, you killed his friends. You haven't given him much reason to trust you so far.
I did what I needed to do to save our goddess. No one would have needed to die had you not forced our hand.
Listen to him Arianwyn, he'd sacrifice everything and everyone just to free whatever is in that temple. Is that really what you want?
Enough of this! You can try to manipulate him all you want, he's made his choice.
Now, I'm afraid I'll need to push you on a decision.
I'm sorry, but we can't let you enter that temple.
A shame. As unlikely as it was, I did hope you might see reason.
I think we're done here then. For what it's worth, I'm sorry it had to end this way.
As am I.
Iorwerth forces approaching!
Incoming!
Elena!
Ha! Looks like you were too slow my friend.
Get away from her!
Or what? Will you murder me in cold blood like you did with King Tyras?
There's only one murderer here!
You can lie to yourself all you want, I know what you are. You enjoy killing, just like I do.
The satisfaction when I finally put an end to that fool Ysgawyn, it was beautiful. It was even better than when I dealt with that stupid lover of his.
But if that wasn't enough, now I get to be the one to finally put an end to you and your pathetic girlfriend!
We'll see about that!
Oh I'm going to enjoy this...
This can't be good...
Go! Get after them!
What about you?
Don't worry, I'll take care of her.
This is it, this is what we've spent the last thousand years fighting for. Today, it will finally all be worth it.
Lord Iorwerth please, see reason. That thing is not Seren, it's not our goddess.
And what would you know?
I knew Seren, I'm the only one here that did, and I know that isn't her.
Time can change a lot of things, perhaps Seren has changed as well.
I... I don't think it's her.
Of course it's her! Don't tell me you believe Baxtorian and his lies?
I may not have met our goddess, but I heard enough stories to know what she looked like. This thing, it's not her.
Well lucky for us, we have a way of finding out.
Lord Iorwerth please, this isn't what we agreed.
I know what we agreed Arianwyn! We agreed to free our goddess, and that's what I'm going to do!
No!
You... you've come to free me?
What's going on? Why's everything so dark?
Dark? All I've ever known is darkness. It's all she gave me.
Seren?
You know of her? How?
Well...
You haven't come to free me at all have you? You're one of her servants!
That's not quite...
I loved her! She made me! But I couldn't be what she wanted, so she abandoned me! And now she can't bear to kill me herself, so she sends you instead!
I don't...
I won't let you! It's not fair! She doesn't get to do this! I don't want it!
Wait!
No! Get out! Get out! Get out!
What... what have you done?
She was confused, she was hurt. Yes, she was angry, but she was innocent!
I tried to stop her...
How? With violence? That's all you know isn't it?
She just needed time, time to understand, time to overcome her pain. She was our goddess, the last hope for our people. And now, she's gone, because of you.
I hope you can live with yourself...
Arianwyn.
How are you doing?
As well as can be expected. My guilt is a heavy load. A lot of people died because of me.
A lot more might have died if you hadn't stopped Lord Iorwerth.
He wasn't evil, not truly. He just became so obsessed with his goal that he forgot why he started fighting in the first place.
As for the fragment of Seren... I wish there had been another way.
She wasn't Seren, and she never would have been.
No, and at least now her pain has ended. Still, I'll always wonder what could have been...
What will you do now?
There's no place for me here anymore, not after what I've done.
You're leaving?
I wanted to stay long enough to help repair the damage of my actions, and to look upon Prifddinas for the first time. I've done that now. Lletya has been rebuilt and Prifddinas has been reformed.
Where will you go?
I don't know. There's a lot of places on this world that I've never seen. Maybe one of them will help me find redemption, and forgiveness.

The elves here will do fine. Baxtorian has his own path of redemption to go on, and I imagine he'll struggle far more than me. He has the other elders to support him though. Under them, our people will prosper.
Anyway, you should get going. Baxtorian will be waiting for you.
I'll miss you.
And I you. Farewell friend.
Ah,. Welcome.
Hey, good to see you both.
And you.
I thought the city had been restored, I don't see anything though.
One of the security measures put in place during the God Wars, from the outside it seems like there's nothing there. Don't worry though, the restoration is complete.
Speaking of which, myself and the other elders have come to an agreement. For too long, we've been afraid of outsiders, showing them mistrust while our own kind plot against us.
After all that's happened, we've decided that from now on, that will no longer be the case. We will open our city up to the other races, letting them walk among us for the first time.
As a thank you for all that you've done, we'd like the two of you to be the first to enter Prifddinas.
Well, that's quite the honour.
They've also agreed to let me move into the city. That tiny house in Ardougne was becoming a bit tiresome, and there's so much for me to learn from the Meilyr elves.
Well I'll be sure to come and visit.
Now that the city has been reformed, are you going to become king of the elves again?

Oh I said my days as a king were done, and I meant it. From now on, the elves will be jointly ruled by the eight clan elders. No single elf will ever rule again. We've realised that we're not overly good at it.
But anyway, we can talk more later. For now, I'd say it's time for the two of you to see Prifddinas.
Ready ?
